title-group.article-title: FROM PERSUASION TO SUBVERSION: A REVIEW OF PAST AND CURRENT TRENDS IN DEFINING RHETORIC

abstract.p: This paper explores the content given to the term rhetoric and some of the history of its changes. It begins with the sophistic emphasis on persuasion as a means of coming to terms with the phenomenal world around us, through to a modern conception of rhetoric as a deconstructive and critical tool in analysing the power-play of meaning that constitutes texts. This paper tries to reflect on some of these changes, arguing that understanding the term implies that one must also examine the surplus of meaning that informs it. While the word rhetoric is highly ambiguous, this paper tries to demonstrate that such ambiguity need not be viewed as a trial and a hindrance in the search for a correct definition as a precursor for effective discussion on the subject. Instead it argues that an investigation into rhetoric's surplus of meaning is perhaps what constitutes effective discussion in the first place, and that further, such surplus of meaning is one that can be characterised as far more unified than commonly assumed which enables one do more with the term rhetoric than previously thought of, or allowed. 'Rhetoric: art of persuasive or impressive speaking or writing; language designed to persuade or impress (often with implication of insincerity or exaggeration etc)' The South African Pocket Oxford Dictionary.
